header.name: chaos/preprocessor/control/branch.h
header.author: Paul Mensonides
header.overview: The header defines a branching control construct.

macro.abstract: The macro selects a branch of execution.

usage.param:
The initial "if" branch. This must be one of the following forms:
(0xIF)(cond)(...) (0xIIF)(bit)(...)
Valid values for the cond argument range from 0 to . Valid values for the bit argument are 0 and 1.

Zero or more "else-if" branches, where each branch is one of the following forms:
(0xELIF)(cond)(...) (0xELIIF)(bit)(...)
Valid values for the cond argument range from 0 to . Valid values for the bit argument are 0 and 1.

The "else" branch. If this branch exists, it must be in the in the following form:
(0xELSE)(...)

The initial "if" branch. This must be one of the following forms:
(0xIF)(cond)(expr) (0xIIF)(bit)(expr)
Valid values for the cond argument range from 0 to . Valid values for the bit argument are 0 and 1.

Zero or more "else-if" branches, where each branch is one of the following forms:
(0xELIF)(cond)(expr) (0xELIIF)(bit)(expr)
Valid values for the cond argument range from 0 to . Valid values for the bit argument are 0 and 1.

The "else" branch. If this branch exists, it must be in the in the following form:
(0xELSE)(expr)

macro.para: Each cond or bit condition is checked in order. If a cond is non-zero or a bit is 1, the entire construct expands to the expr or __VA_ARGS__ associated with the associated branch. If all cond and bit conditions evaluate to 0, this macro expands to the expr or __VA_ARGS__ associated with the "else" branch. If no "else" branch exists, this macro expands to nothing.

The behavior of this macro is illustrated in the following example:
(0xIF)(X)(A) (0xELIF)(Y)(B) (0xELIF)(Z)(C) (0xELSE)(D) (0xENDIF)
In this example, if X evaluates to non-zero, the entire construct, from to (0xENDIF) expands to A. Otherwise, if Y evaluates to non-zero, the construct expands to B. Otherwise, if Z evaluates to non-zero, the construct expands to C. Otherwise, the construct expands to D.

Note that any number of "else-if" branches may exist, though no "else-if" branches are required. Also note that the "else" branch need not exist. For example, the following lines are roughly equivalent to (bit)(expr) and (bit)(T, F) respectively:
(0xIIF)(bit)(expr)(0xENDIF) (0xIIF)(bit)(T)(0xELSEIF)(F)(0xENDIF)
They are not equivalent because the construct expands to a value that cannot directly expand against trailing invocations such as,
#define A() !
(0xIIF)(1)(A)(0xENDIF)() // A () (1)(A)() // !
In order to make the above expand as desired, the result of needs to be "cleaned" with an identity macro such as .
((0xIIF)(1)(A)(0xENDIF))() // !
In C99, the case above is also not equivalent because only the "else" branch of the invocation may be variadic.

Every element of this branching construct is lazy. In other words, the expr or __VA_ARGS__ for a particular branch is not evaluated unless it is selected. Further, each cond or bit is not evaluates unless all previous cond and bit values evaluated to 0.
#define VALID() 1 #define INVALID() VALID(!) // too many arguments
(0xIIF)(1)( VALID() ) (0xELIIF)(INVALID())( INVALID() ) (0xENDIF)
If any one of the INVALID() invocations was actually invoked, and error would be produced. Because the construct is lazy, however, none of the INVALID() invocations is invoked.
